citations.narrative:
During the first day of this inspection, it was noted that the licensee acquired two, one-year-old spider monkeys ("Mike"
and "Jones"). The current license permits only Classes 1-4 of non-human primates; spider monkeys are a brachiating
species, categorized as Class 6. During the second day of this inspection, these spider monkeys were no longer present,
and an employee stated that the former owner that surrendered the animals to the facility changed her mind and wanted
to reclaim the animals.
Licenses authorizing the use of specific species types in subparts D and F are issued based upon successful passing of a
pre-licensing or re-licensing inspection to verify that the licensee is presently equipped and able to provide the appropriate
husbandry and veterinary care needs of the species they possess or will possess for use in covered activity. The facility
must apply for and secure a license to include Class 6 non-human primates before obtaining these animals for use in
covered activities or housing them among animals used in covered activity.
TO BE CORRECTED FROM THE DATE OF THIS INSPECTION ON 01/14/2025

There is no record of disposition for one adult great horned owl that was present at the last inspection but not present at
the time of this inspection. There is no record of acquisition for one adult female canary and one adult male canary
present at this inspection.
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and
correctly disclose the required information; these records must be furnished within a reasonable amount of time and as
may be specified in the request for information.

There is an acquisition record for two, one-year-old male spider monkeys named "Mike" and "Jones" (reportedly
surrendered to the the licensee from a client) that does not list the driver's license number and state (or photographic
identification card for non-drivers issued by a state) for the relinquishing owner's name as required in the absence of a
USDA license or registration number. Another acquisition form for an adult male macaque named "Petey" (which lists only
the word "bennet" in the species field) is missing the driver's license and state and the vehicle license number and state
that should be provided in the absence of a USDA license or registration number. Neither acquisition form lists the
licensee's name and address as the receiver of the animal.
Records containing the required information for animals disposed of, or acquired for, use in regulated activities (including
those offspring born on premises) are necessary to accurately track animals to ensure their humane care and use. The
licensee must make and maintain records of the inventory, acquisition and disposition of all animals which fully and
correctly disclose the required information; these records must be furnished within a reasonable time and as may be
specified in the request for the information.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 01/31/2025

A facility employee stated that they believed an annual review of the Contingency Plan was done in October of 2024, but
there were no records to document this.
The licensee must ensure not only that a Contingency Plan is in place, but also that it is reviewed at least once annually
to ensure it adequately addresses the criteria listed in paragraph (a) of this section and is still relevant to the facility and
animals. The plan must provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in
the event of an emergency or disaster. The licensee must maintain documentation of the annual review, including
documenting any amendments or changes made to the plan since the previous year's review.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 02/16/2025

The indoor portion of the primary enclosure housing one adult male ring-tailed lemur named "Maurice" has rusted areas of
metal, some of which have rusted through on the lower metal bars to produce holes and sharp points.
Rusted metal is porous and cannot be easily cleaned and sanitized; rusted-through metal creates sharp points that can
injure the animals. The licensee must ensure that any surfaces that come in contact with non-human primates are free of
excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation or that affects the structural strength of the surfaces, and
that all surfaces are free of jagged edges or sharp points.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the onset of this inspection, there were two one-year-old male spider monkeys with minimal enrichment inside their
primary enclosure, and no enrichment provided specifically to facilitate brachiating locomotion. The enclosure contained
only a wooden log on the floor, a hanging fabric hammock/pouch and two blankets. These animals were not present the
following day during the continuation of the inspection; the facility representative stated the animals were reclaimed by
their former owner.
True brachiation in this enclosure is not possible for these animals due to lack of enrichment and structures that would
allow this species-specific behavior. Failure to provide structures for normal behavior and movement of species such as
brachiating nonhuman primates may result in deteriorating health and psychological welfare. The licensee must ensure
that physical environment in the primary enclosures is enriched by providing means of expressing non-injurious species-
typical activities.
CORRECTED BY THE END OF THIS INSPECTION ON 01/15/2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
In the outdoor portion of the enclosure containing one adult male ring-tailed lemur named "Maurice" there are heavy
accumulations of bird excreta from wild birds on the low hanging foliage of the trees, the dirt and cement floor, and
enrichment items.
Bird droppings can contaminate food and water and spread disease to non-human primates. The licensee must establish
and maintain an effective program for control of birds and mammals that are pests, so as to promote the health and well-
being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.

In the enclosure housing one adult, male African crested porcupine there is an area of approximately eight square feet
under a bridge feature where the animal dug and exposed the buried wire grid paneling, creating spaces large enough for
his feet to pass through.
Exposed wire with large holes under an animal can result in injury or entrapment. A system of facility monitoring should be
in place to ensure all enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from illness
or injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning.
